results.title: The Burnie story
results.creator_credit: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service
results.brief_description: The township of Burnie on the north-west coast of Tasmania with a population of 14,000 is the centre of the thriving pulp and paper manufacturing industry. This industry started in 1936 and produces from the forests in the surrounding country, not only timber for the building industry but from the timber waste all types of cardboard, and wrapping paper and even high-grade printing paper. The film shows the up-to-date and powerful machinery which is used from the time a tree is felled until the final paper product is shipped from the Burnie wharves. Afforestation is maintained to ensure the raw material will not be exhausted. Photography: Geoffrey Thompson. Narrated by Ray Chapman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Associated Pulp and Paper Manufacturers and Cine Service

results.title: Brisbane
results.creator_credit: Robert Parker, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Shows a typical Australian family in the city of Brisbane going about their daily life.

results.title: The Blowfly menace
results.creator_credit: A. C. McKay BVSc and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: For farmers and graziers this study of the life-cycle of the green blowfly and other flies associated with blowfly strike in sheep, and demonstrations of various methods of control, should prove both useful and interesting.

results.title: Birds and billabongs
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Records the 1948 Arnhem Land Expedition, sponsored by the national Geographic Society, the Smithsonian Institute of America and the Commonwealth Government. Shows various types of birds found in Arnhem Land including terns, plovers, Burdekin ducks, sharp-tailed sand pipers, geese, royal spoonbills, the snake bird, brolgas, white necked heron, the egret and the lotus bird. The sound track includes actual recordings of bird song.

results.title: Behind the big top
results.brief_description: Wirth’s circus comes to town! The arrival of the circus at Melbourne and their preparations for a performance. Suitable for children 6+ years old.
results.description: Wirth’s circus comes to town! The arrival of the circus at Melbourne and their preparations for a performance. Suitable for children 6+ years old.

results.title: Before production begins
results.brief_description: The story of the birth of a new Holden car, from an artist’s conception, through the modelling of small and full scale models, to the making of the first prototype model. From the hundreds of scale drawings, skilled craftsmen create by hand, the hundreds of engine and body components of the prototype. Laboratory and road tests of components and the completed prototype ensue that every section of the car conforms to rigid engineering specifications. Only after all this preliminary work can mass production begin on a new model Holden car.

results.title: Barrier story
results.creator_credit: Hugh Alexander, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows the city and people of Broken Hill, situated on one of the richest silver, lead and zinc fields in the world. Emphasis is laid on the rapid development of Broken Hill into a modern mining community with all the facilities for pleasant living and recreation. There is wealth and security, social progress and industrial peace in the ‘Barrier City’.

results.title: Australian weekend
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Small and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Indicates some of the ways in which Australians find recreation in their weekends. The people of Sydney go surfing, yachting, hiking, fishing, or playing cricket, bowls or golf during the day, and dance on the foreshores of the harbour at night. Music but no commentary.

results.title: Australian reporter
results.brief_description: Magazine film comprising three items: Asian concert in Sydney at the Conservatorium of Music, asian students present a concert in aid of the Royal Blind Society; Young farmers, this movement introduces boys and girls to the science (and chores) of modern farming; Radio Australia, this international station uses experts from overseas and well-stocked libraries to maintain world-wide appeal. No other credits available.
